editorialDecl.p: A taxonomy of author and editor roles referenced by The New Handbook of Syriac Literature.

category.gloss: A person whose authorship or editing of the work has been claimed, whether by herself/himself or by others.
category.desc: This role indicates that the Syriaca.org editors have either not attempted or not found it possible to label the person's role with a more precise categorization. This role or its sub-roles may be used on either an author or an editor tag. Unlike using an author or editor tag without a role attribute, using this role or its sub-roles (except where otherwise noted) does not justify expressing the work-person relationship with the RDF properties dct:creator, schema:creator, schema:author, or schema:editor, since the claim denoted by this role may be incorrect.

category.gloss: A person whom others have credited at any time with the authorship or editing of a work, regardless of whether or not the person is an actual author or editor of the work.
category.desc: The use of this role indicates that the Syriaca.org editors either are uncertain regarding the correctness of this attribution or have not attempted to determine its correctness. An attribution determined to be false should use the #incorrectly-attributed role, whereas an attribution determined to be correct will not necessarily be labeled with any role. The attributed role should also be distinguished from a person whose identity was claimed pseudonymously by the author or editor of the work himself or herself.

category.gloss: A person whom others have erroneously credited at any time with the authorship or editing of a work.
category.desc: This role indicates that the Syriaca.org editors consider the attribution to be definitely false. An attribution of uncertain accuracy should use the #attributed role. False attribution should also be distinguished from a person whose identity was claimed pseudonymously by the author or editor of the work himself or herself.

category.gloss: A person whose authorship or editing of the work has been significantly disputed in scholarly literature, and who may or may not actually be an author or editor of the work.
category.desc: The use of this role indicates that the Syriaca.org editors either are uncertain regarding which way to resolve this dispute or have not attempted to do so. This role may be used together with the role #attributed, meaning that a person's role may be both disputed and attributed.

category.gloss: A person whose authorship or editing of the work has been rightly disputed in scholarly literature.
category.desc: The use of this role indicates that the Syriaca.org editors think the evidence weighs against this person being an author or editor of the work, but want to alert the reader to the fact that this has been debated. This role may be used together with the role #incorrectly-attributed.

category.gloss: A person whose authorship or editing of the work has been wrongly disputed in scholarly literature.
category.desc: The use of this role indicates that the Syriaca.org editors think the evidence weighs in favor of this person being an author or editor of the work, but want to alert the reader to the fact that this has been debated. This role may be used together with the role #attributed. This role also implies that the relationship of the work [subject] to the person [object] can be expressed by the RDF properties dct:creator and schema:author.

category.gloss: A person who was not the work's author or editor, but whose identity was assumed by an author or editor of the work.
category.desc: This should be distinguished from an #attributed author or editor who has been credited with the work by others.

This role does not need to be labeled explicitly, as it is implied by any editor tag that does not have a role attribute. This category is merely a container for more precise editorial categories. The sub-roles contained in this role should be used only with an editor tag (not with an author tag). The use of this role implies that the relationship of the work (subject) to the person (object) can be expressed by the RDF properties dct:contributor and schema:editor, unless the sub-role definition indicates otherwise.

category.gloss: A person directly responsible for the creation of a specific document.
category.desc: In particular, Syriaca.org uses this role to indicate the person who created a Syriaca.org record, even if it was created on the basis of pre-existing data. The use of this role implies that the relationship of the work (subject) to the person (object) can be expressed by the RDF properties dct:creator, schema:creator, and schema:author.

category.gloss: A person who has the official title of "general editor" for a work.
category.desc: Syriaca.org uses this role especially to designate a person with editorial oversight for a Syriaca.org resource.

category.gloss: A person responsible for compiling, rearranging, abbreviating, or interpolating text in a work.
category.desc: The use of this role rather than its sub-roles indicates that the Syriaca.org editors are uncertain regarding the person's more precise role in relation to the work, or have not tried to determine it.

category.gloss: A person responsible for abbreviating the text of a work, whether by removing text or by summarizing or paraphrasing it.
category.desc: This role may be used alone or together with other roles to describe the activity of an editor.

category.gloss: A person responsible for rearranging or reordering the text of a work.
category.desc: This role may be used alone or together with other roles to describe the activity of an editor.

category.gloss: A person responsible for compiling the text of a work from multiple sources.
category.desc: This role may be used alone or together with other roles to describe the activity of an editor.

category.gloss: A person responsible for an insertion in the text of a work.
category.desc: This role may be used alone or together with other roles to describe the activity of an editor.

category.gloss: A person who copied the text of the work onto a physical object.
category.desc: A person with this role is specified for a work [rather than a manuscript] only when the text-bearing object is now lost or unknown.

category.gloss: A person responsible for rendering the text of the work into a different language.
category.desc: Since translation often involves other editorial activities, the Syriaca.org editors may, at their discretion, additionally label this person with the role of #redactor (or one of its sub-roles), but the lack of a specified redactor role does not imply that the translator was not also a redactor. The use of this role implies that the relationship of the work (subject) to the person (object) can be expressed by the RDF property schema:translator.

body.head: Author and Editor Roles used in The New Handbook of Syriac Literature
body.p:
The New Handbook of Syriac Literature
uses the vocabulary defined here to specify the roles of persons in relation to works. Regrettably, it is not always possible for the editors to investigate the precise roles of authors or editors, especially in the cases where our information is based on datasets that were contributed by external scholars or projects. This means that an author's or editor's role is sometimes not designated when it could be, or that it may be a generic role (such as #redactor or #attributed) when it could be more specific (such as #abbreviator or #incorrectly-attributed). We warmly invite readers to suggest a more precise role by using the "Corrections/Additions?" button on the page for the relevant work and supplying a reliable source for the information.
An author or editor may have multiple roles, so long as the definitions of those roles do not contradict one another. Also, authors should not have roles that are reserved for editors only.

Technical Discussion: This vocabulary defines the values allowed for the role attribute on author and editor tags on Syriaca.org pages.
role Attribute Definition and Examples
The definition for the role attribute in TEI-XML can be found at . See also the examples for editor/@role at .
Multiple Values
Multiple values should be separated with a whitespace. Multiple values are allowed as long as their definitions are not contradictory. For example, author role="#attributed #disputed" is permissible, whereas author role="#correctly-attributed #incorrectly-attributed" is not.
Editor-Only Roles
Roles in the category #editor should only be used on editor tags, not on author tags.
RDF Properties
Relevant RDF properties are noted in this taxonomy. These are intended to give guidance for how the work-person relationship can be expressed in RDF, but they are not exact equivalents and in some cases are much more generic than the Syriaca.org roles. For Syriaca.org work records, the RDF properties for TEI author tags that do not have a role attribute are dct:creator and schema:author. For editor tags without a role attribute, the relevant properties are dct:contributor and schema:editor.
